blurb: The Middle Discourses (Majjhima Nikāya, abbreviated MN) is a collection of 152 discourses in the Pali canon (Tipiṭaka) of the Theravada school of Buddhism. The word “middle” refers to the length of the individual discourses. This is perhaps the most popular collection of early discourses. It contains a wide variety of teachings, many of them presented as narratives between the Buddha and a diverse range of his contemporaries. The collection parallels the Madhyamāgama (MA) of the Sarvāstivāda school, which survives as a translation in the Chinese canon.

blurb: The Buddha examines how the notion of a permanent self emerges from the process of perception. A wide range of phenomena are considered, embracing both naturalistic and cosmological dimensions. An unawakened person interprets experience in terms of a self, while those more advanced have the same experiences without attachment.

blurb: Here the Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This collects many of the meditation teachings found throughout the canon, especially the foundational practices focusing on the body, and is regarded as one of the most important meditation discourses.

name: The Shorter Elephant’s Footprint Simile

main_text.mn33:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
main_text.mn33:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
main_text.mn33:10.1: And how does a mendicant not know satisfaction?
main_text.mn33:10.2: It’s when a mendicant, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, finds no inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds no joy connected with the teaching.
main_text.mn33:10.3: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know satisfaction.
main_text.mn33:11.1: And how does a mendicant not know the trail?
main_text.mn33:11.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the noble eightfold path.
main_text.mn33:11.3: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know the trail.
main_text.mn33:12.1: And how is a mendicant not skilled in pastures?
main_text.mn33:12.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
main_text.mn33:12.3: That’s how a mendicant is not skilled in pastures.
main_text.mn33:13.1: And how does a mendicant milk dry?
main_text.mn33:13.2: It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, and that mendicant doesn’t know moderation in accepting.
main_text.mn33:13.3: That’s how a mendicant milks dry.
main_text.mn33:14.1: And how does a mendicant not show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?
main_text.mn33:14.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t consistently treat senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
main_text.mn33:14.5: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
main_text.mn33:14.6: A mendicant with these eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
main_text.mn33:15.1: A cowherd with eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
main_text.mn33:15.3: It’s when a cowherd knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, smokes out pests, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd.
main_text.mn33:15.4: A cowherd with these eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
main_text.mn33:16.1: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
main_text.mn33:16.3: It’s when a mendicant knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, smokes out pests, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
main_text.mn33:17.1: And how does a mendicant know form?
main_text.mn33:17.2: It’s when a mendicant truly understands that all form is the four primary elements, or form derived from the four primary elements.
main_text.mn33:17.3: That’s how a mendicant knows form.
main_text.mn33:18.1: And how is a mendicant skilled in characteristics?
main_text.mn33:18.2: It’s when a mendicant understands that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds.

main_text.mn41:12.3: They give up stealing. They don’t, with the intention to commit theft, take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.
main_text.mn41:12.4: They give up sexual misconduct. They don’t have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They don’t have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.
main_text.mn41:12.5: This is how principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of body.
main_text.mn41:13.1: And how is principled and moral conduct fourfold by way of speech?
main_text.mn41:13.2: It’s when a certain person gives up lying. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, mister, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I see.’ So they don’t deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.
main_text.mn41:13.3: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
main_text.mn41:13.4: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable, and agreeable to the people.
main_text.mn41:13.5: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
main_text.mn41:13.6: This is how principled and moral conduct is fourfold by way of speech.
main_text.mn41:14.1: And how is principled and moral conduct threefold by way of mind?
main_text.mn41:14.2: It's when a certain person is not covetous. They don’t covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’
main_text.mn41:14.3: They have a kind heart and loving intentions: ‘May these sentient beings live free of enmity and ill will, untroubled and happy!’
main_text.mn41:14.4: They have right view, an undistorted perspective:
main_text.mn41:14.5: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There is obligation to mother and father. There are beings reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are well attained and practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
main_text.mn41:14.6: This is how principled and moral conduct is threefold by way of mind.
main_text.mn41:14.7: This is how principled and moral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
main_text.mn41:15.1: A person of principled and moral conduct might wish:
main_text.mn41:15.2: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats!’
main_text.mn41:15.3: It’s possible that this might happen.
main_text.mn41:15.5: Because they have principled and moral conduct.

main_text.mn41:2.1: The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard,
main_text.mn41:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
main_text.mn41:2.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
main_text.mn41:2.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
main_text.mn41:2.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing.
main_text.mn41:2.7: He reveals an entirely full and pure spiritual life.
main_text.mn41:2.8: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
main_text.mn41:3.1: Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Seated to one side they said to the Buddha:
main_text.mn41:4.1: “What is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell?
main_text.mn41:4.2: And what is the cause, Master Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?”
main_text.mn41:43.1: A person of principled and moral conduct might wish:
main_text.mn41:43.2: ‘If only I might realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
main_text.mn41:43.3: It’s possible that this might happen.
main_text.mn41:43.5: Because they have principled and moral conduct.”
main_text.mn41:44.1: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Sālā said to the Buddha,
main_text.mn41:44.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
main_text.mn41:44.4: We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
main_text.mn41:44.5: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
main_text.mn41:5.1: “Unprincipled and immoral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
main_text.mn41:5.2: Principled and moral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”
main_text.mn41:6.1: “We don’t understand the detailed meaning of Master Gotama’s brief statement.
main_text.mn41:6.2: Master Gotama, please teach us this matter in detail so we can understand the meaning.”
main_text.mn41:6.3: “Well then, householders, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
main_text.mn41:7.1: “Householders, unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of body, fourfold by way of speech, and threefold by way of mind.
main_text.mn41:8.1: And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct threefold by way of body?
main_text.mn41:8.2: It’s when a certain person kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
main_text.mn41:8.3: They steal. With the intention to commit theft, they take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.
main_text.mn41:8.4: They commit sexual misconduct. They have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.
main_text.mn41:8.5: This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of body.
main_text.mn41:9.1: And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct fourfold by way of speech?
main_text.mn41:9.2: It’s when a certain person lies. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, mister, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ So they deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.
main_text.mn41:9.3: They speak divisively. They repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. And so they divide those who are harmonious, supporting division, delighting in division, loving division, speaking words that promote division.
main_text.mn41:9.4: They speak harshly. They use the kinds of words that are cruel, nasty, hurtful, offensive, bordering on anger, not leading to immersion.
main_text.mn41:9.5: They talk nonsense. Their speech is untimely, and is neither factual nor beneficial. It has nothing to do with the teaching or the training. Their words have no value, and are untimely, unreasonable, rambling, and pointless.
main_text.mn41:9.6: This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is fourfold by way of speech.

blurb: A series of questions and answers between Sāriputta and Mahākoṭṭhita, examining various subtle and abstruse aspects of the teachings.

main_text.mn43:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
main_text.mn43:1.3: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.
main_text.mn43:1.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Sāriputta:
main_text.mn43:10.1: “What can be known by purified mind consciousness released from the five senses?”
main_text.mn43:10.2: “Aware that ‘space is infinite’ it can know the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’ it can know the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’ it can know the dimension of nothingness.”
main_text.mn43:11.1: “How do you understand something that can be known?”
main_text.mn43:11.2: “You understand something that can be known with the eye of wisdom.”
main_text.mn43:12.2: “The purpose of wisdom is direct knowledge, complete understanding, and giving up.”
main_text.mn43:13.1: “How many conditions are there for the arising of right view?”
main_text.mn43:13.2: “There are two conditions for the arising of right view:
main_text.mn43:13.3: the words of another and proper attention.
main_text.mn43:13.4: These are the two conditions for the arising of right view.”
main_text.mn43:14.1: “When right view is supported by how many factors does it have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit?”
main_text.mn43:14.2: “When right view is supported by five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.
main_text.mn43:14.3: It’s when right view is supported by ethics, learning, discussion, serenity, and discernment.
main_text.mn43:14.4: When right view is supported by these five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.”
main_text.mn43:15.1: “How many states of existence are there?”
main_text.mn43:15.2: “Reverend, there are these three states of existence.
main_text.mn43:15.3: Existence in the sensual realm, the realm of luminous form, and the formless realm.”
main_text.mn43:16.1: “But how is there rebirth into a new state of existence in the future?”
main_text.mn43:16.2: “It’s because of sentient beings—hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving—taking pleasure in various different realms.
main_text.mn43:16.3: That’s how there is rebirth into a new state of existence in the future.”
main_text.mn43:17.1: “But how is there no rebirth into a new state of existence in the future?”
main_text.mn43:17.2: “It’s when ignorance fades away, knowledge arises, and craving ceases.
main_text.mn43:17.3: That’s how there is no rebirth into a new state of existence in the future.”
main_text.mn43:18.1: “But what, reverend, is the first absorption?”
main_text.mn43:18.2: “Reverend, it’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
main_text.mn43:18.3: This is called the first absorption.”
main_text.mn43:19.1: “But how many factors does the first absorption have?”
main_text.mn43:19.3: When a mendicant has entered the first absorption, placing the mind, keeping it connected, rapture, bliss, and unification of mind are present.
main_text.mn43:19.4: That’s how the first absorption has five factors.”
main_text.mn43:2.2: How is a witless person defined?”
main_text.mn43:2.3: “Reverend, they’re called witless because they don’t understand.
main_text.mn43:2.5: They don’t understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
main_text.mn43:2.6: They’re called witless because they don’t understand.”
main_text.mn43:2.7: Saying “Good, reverend,” Mahākoṭṭhita approved and agreed with what Sāriputta said. Then he asked another question:
main_text.mn43:20.1: “But how many factors has the first absorption given up and how many does it possess?”
main_text.mn43:20.2: “The first absorption has given up five factors and possesses five factors.
main_text.mn43:20.3: When a mendicant has entered the first absorption, sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt are given up.
main_text.mn43:20.4: Placing the mind, keeping it connected, rapture, bliss, and unification of mind are present.
main_text.mn43:20.5: That’s how the first absorption has given up five factors and possesses five factors.”
main_text.mn43:21.1: “Reverend, these five faculties have different scopes and different ranges, and don’t experience each others’ scope and range. That is,
main_text.mn43:21.2: the faculties of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.
main_text.mn43:21.3: What do these five faculties, with their different scopes and ranges, have recourse to? What experiences their scopes and ranges?”
main_text.mn43:21.6: “These five faculties, with their different scopes and ranges, have recourse to the mind. And the mind experiences their scopes and ranges.”
main_text.mn43:22.11: “Just now I understood you to say:
main_text.mn43:22.13: But I also understood you to say:
main_text.mn43:22.15: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”
main_text.mn43:22.16: “Well then, reverend, I shall give you a simile.
main_text.mn43:22.17: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
main_text.mn43:22.18: Suppose there was an oil lamp burning. The light appears dependent on the flame, and the flame appears dependent on the light.
main_text.mn43:22.19: In the same way, life depends on warmth to continue, and warmth depends on life to continue.”
main_text.mn43:22.3: “These five faculties depend on what to continue?”
main_text.mn43:22.6: “These five faculties depend on life to continue.”
main_text.mn43:22.7: “But what does life depend on to continue?”
main_text.mn43:22.9: “But what does warmth depend on to continue?”
main_text.mn43:23.1: “Are the life forces the same things as the phenomena that are felt? Or are they different things?”
main_text.mn43:23.2: “The life forces are not the same things as the phenomena that are felt.
main_text.mn43:23.3: For if the life forces and the phenomena that are felt were the same things, a mendicant who had attained the cessation of perception and feeling would not emerge from it.
main_text.mn43:23.4: But because the life forces and the phenomena that are felt are different things, a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling can emerge from it.”
main_text.mn43:24.1: “How many things must this body lose before it lies forsaken, tossed aside like an insentient log?”
main_text.mn43:24.2: “This body must lose three things before it lies forsaken, tossed aside like an insentient log: vitality, warmth, and consciousness.”
main_text.mn43:25.1: “What’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling?”
main_text.mn43:25.2: “When someone dies, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled; their vitality is spent; their warmth is dissipated; and their faculties have disintegrated.
main_text.mn43:25.3: When a mendicant has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, their physical, verbal, and mental processes have ceased and stilled. But their vitality is not spent; their warmth is not dissipated; and their faculties are very clear.
main_text.mn43:25.4: That’s the difference between someone who has passed away and a mendicant who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling.”
main_text.mn43:26.1: “How many conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart?”
main_text.mn43:26.2: “Four conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart.
main_text.mn43:26.3: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
main_text.mn43:26.4: These four conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart.”
main_text.mn43:27.1: “How many conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart?”
main_text.mn43:27.2: “Two conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart:
main_text.mn43:27.3: not focusing on any signs, and focusing on the signless.
main_text.mn43:27.4: These two conditions are necessary to attain the signless release of the heart.”
main_text.mn43:27.5: “How many conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart?”
main_text.mn43:28.1: “Three conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart:
main_text.mn43:28.2: not focusing on any signs, focusing on the signless, and a previous determination.
main_text.mn43:28.3: These three conditions are necessary to remain in the signless release of the heart.”
main_text.mn43:29.1: “How many conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart?”
main_text.mn43:29.2: “Two conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart:
main_text.mn43:29.3: focusing on all signs, and not focusing on the signless.
main_text.mn43:29.4: These two conditions are necessary to emerge from the signless release of the heart.”
main_text.mn43:29.5: “The limitless release of the heart, and the release of the heart through nothingness, and the release of the heart through emptiness, and the signless release of the heart: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
main_text.mn43:3.2: How is a wise person defined?”
main_text.mn43:3.5: They understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
main_text.mn43:3.6: They’re called wise because they understand.”
main_text.mn43:30.1: “There is a way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
main_text.mn43:30.2: But there’s also a way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.
main_text.mn43:31.1: And what’s the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing?
main_text.mn43:31.2: Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
main_text.mn43:31.3: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …
main_text.mn43:31.4: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
main_text.mn43:31.5: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
main_text.mn43:31.6: This is called the limitless release of the heart.
main_text.mn43:32.1: And what is the release of the heart through nothingness?
main_text.mn43:32.2: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
main_text.mn43:32.3: This is called the heart’s release through nothingness.
main_text.mn43:33.1: And what is the release of the heart through emptiness?
main_text.mn43:33.2: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
main_text.mn43:33.3: ‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’
main_text.mn43:33.4: This is called the release of the heart through emptiness.
main_text.mn43:34.1: And what is the signless release of the heart?
main_text.mn43:34.2: It’s when a mendicant, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.
main_text.mn43:34.3: This is called the signless release of the heart.
main_text.mn43:34.4: This is the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
main_text.mn43:35.1: And what’s the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?
main_text.mn43:35.2: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of limits.
main_text.mn43:35.3: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.
main_text.mn43:35.4: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of limitless release of the heart.
main_text.mn43:35.5: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
main_text.mn43:36.1: Greed is something, hate is something, and delusion is something.
main_text.mn43:36.2: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.
main_text.mn43:36.3: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of release of the heart through nothingness.
main_text.mn43:36.4: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
main_text.mn43:37.1: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of signs.
main_text.mn43:37.2: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.
main_text.mn43:37.3: The unshakable release of the heart is said to be the best kind of signless release of the heart.
main_text.mn43:37.4: That unshakable release of the heart is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
main_text.mn43:37.5: This is the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”
main_text.mn43:37.6: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.
main_text.mn43:37.7: Satisfied, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita was happy with what Sāriputta said.
main_text.mn43:4.6: It’s called consciousness because it cognizes.”
main_text.mn43:5.2: are these things mixed or separate?
main_text.mn43:5.3: And can we completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them?”
main_text.mn43:5.5: these things are mixed, not separate.
main_text.mn43:5.6: And you can never completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them.
main_text.mn43:5.7: For you understand what you cognize, and you cognize what you understand.
main_text.mn43:5.8: That’s why these things are mixed, not separate.
main_text.mn43:5.9: And you can never completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them.”
main_text.mn43:6.2: what is the difference between these things that are mixed, not separate?”
main_text.mn43:6.4: “The difference between these things is that wisdom should be developed, while consciousness should be completely understood.”
main_text.mn43:7.5: It feels pleasure, pain, and neutral.
main_text.mn43:7.6: It’s called feeling because it feels.”
main_text.mn43:8.5: It perceives blue, yellow, red, and white.
main_text.mn43:8.6: It’s called perception because it perceives.”
main_text.mn43:9.2: are these things mixed or separate?

main_text.mn43:9.5: these things are mixed, not separate.
main_text.mn43:9.6: And you can never completely dissect them so as to describe the difference between them.
main_text.mn43:9.7: For you perceive what you feel, and you cognize what you perceive.

main_text.mn44:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

main_text.mn44:11.3: Right speech, right action, and right livelihood: these things are included in the category of ethics.
main_text.mn44:11.4: Right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion: these things are included in the category of immersion.
main_text.mn44:11.5: Right view and right thought: these things are included in the category of wisdom.”
main_text.mn44:12.1: “But ma’am, what is immersion? What things are the foundations of immersion? What things are the prerequisites for immersion? What is the development of immersion?”
main_text.mn44:12.3: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the foundations of immersion.
main_text.mn44:12.4: The four right efforts are the prerequisites for immersion.
main_text.mn44:12.5: The cultivation, development, and making much of these very same things is the development of immersion.”
main_text.mn44:14.1: “But ma’am, what is the physical process? What’s the verbal process? What’s the mental process?”
main_text.mn44:14.2: “Breathing is a physical process. Placing the mind and keeping it connected are verbal processes. Perception and feeling are mental processes.”
main_text.mn44:15.1: “But ma’am, why is breathing a physical process? Why are placing the mind and keeping it connected verbal processes? Why are perception and feeling mental processes?”
main_text.mn44:15.2: “Breathing is physical. It’s tied up with the body, that’s why breathing is a physical process.
main_text.mn44:15.3: First you place the mind and keep it connected, then you break into speech. That’s why placing the mind and keeping it connected are verbal processes.
main_text.mn44:15.4: Perception and feeling are mental. They’re tied up with the mind, that’s why perception and feeling are mental processes.”
main_text.mn44:16.1: “But ma’am, how does someone attain the cessation of perception and feeling?”

main_text.mn44:18.1: “But ma’am, how does someone emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling?”

main_text.mn44:19.1: “But ma’am, which arise first for a mendicant who is emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental processes?”
main_text.mn44:19.2: “Mental processes arise first, then physical, then verbal.”

main_text.mn44:9.2: “It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

main_text.mn51:24.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
main_text.mn51:24.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
main_text.mn51:25.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
main_text.mn51:25.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
main_text.mn51:26.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

main_text.mn51:8.1: “And what person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves? It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared for them, or an invitation for a meal.
main_text.mn51:8.10: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
main_text.mn51:8.11: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
main_text.mn51:8.12: They’re committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening.
main_text.mn51:8.13: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
main_text.mn51:8.14: This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
main_text.mn51:8.2: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer.
main_text.mn51:8.3: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
main_text.mn51:8.4: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
main_text.mn51:8.5: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
main_text.mn51:8.6: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
main_text.mn51:8.7: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
main_text.mn51:8.8: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
main_text.mn51:9.1: And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
main_text.mn51:9.2: It’s when a person is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, or poultry, a hunter or trapper, a fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher, a jailer, or someone with some other kind of cruel livelihood.
main_text.mn51:9.3: This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

main_text.mn53:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
main_text.mn53:10.1: And how is a noble disciple dedicated to wakefulness?
main_text.mn53:10.2: It’s when a noble disciple practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying their mind from obstacles.

main_text.mn76:8.11: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
main_text.mn76:8.12: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that both of us are annihilated and destroyed when our body breaks up, and we don’t exist after death.
main_text.mn76:8.13: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go naked, shaven, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, perfumes, and makeup, and accepting gold and money. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
main_text.mn76:8.14: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
main_text.mn76:8.2: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
main_text.mn76:9.1: This is the first way that negates the spiritual life.

main_text.mn77:26.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.

main_text.mn77:34.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
main_text.mn77:34.2: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
main_text.mn77:34.3: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives.
main_text.mn77:34.4: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
main_text.mn77:35.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

main_text.mn94:10.1: “What person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves?
main_text.mn94:10.11: They squat, committed to persisting in the squatting position.
main_text.mn94:10.12: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
main_text.mn94:10.13: They’re committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening.
main_text.mn94:10.14: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
main_text.mn94:10.15: This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
main_text.mn94:10.2: It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on purpose for them, or an invitation for a meal.
main_text.mn94:10.3: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer.
main_text.mn94:10.4: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
main_text.mn94:10.5: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
main_text.mn94:10.6: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
main_text.mn94:10.7: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
main_text.mn94:10.8: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
main_text.mn94:10.9: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
main_text.mn94:11.1: And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
main_text.mn94:11.2: It’s when a person is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood.
main_text.mn94:11.3: This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.
main_text.mn94:12.1: And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
main_text.mn94:12.2: It’s when a person is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
main_text.mn94:12.3: He has a new temple built to the east of the city. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the temple with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.
main_text.mn94:12.4: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.
main_text.mn94:12.5: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the remainder.
main_text.mn94:12.7: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’
main_text.mn94:12.8: His bondservants, employees, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
main_text.mn94:12.9: This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

main_text.mn94:14.1: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
main_text.mn94:14.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
main_text.mn94:14.3: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
main_text.mn94:15.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan.
main_text.mn94:15.2: They gain faith in the Realized One,
main_text.mn94:15.4: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
main_text.mn94:15.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
main_text.mn94:15.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
main_text.mn94:15.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
main_text.mn94:15.8: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.
main_text.mn94:16.1: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
main_text.mn94:16.10: They avoid beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, perfumes, and makeup.
main_text.mn94:16.11: They avoid high and luxurious beds.
main_text.mn94:16.12: They avoid receiving gold and money,
main_text.mn94:16.2: They give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.
main_text.mn94:16.21: They avoid running errands and messages;
